arguments.file_text:
#!/usr/bin/env python3
import time
import random

# This bench simulates the overhead difference between many per-item remote gets
# vs a single batched get, which mirrors the optimization applied in
# vllm/executor/ray_gpu_executor.py for Ray worker initialization.

N = 20000
random.seed(0)
workers = [f"worker-{i}" for i in range(N)]
# Deterministic pseudo-IPs for workers
ips = [f"10.0.{i % 256}.{(i * 7) % 256}" for i in range(N)]

# Simulate per-item remote get with a tiny overhead to emulate control-plane cost
# Keep this very small so the benchmark runs quickly while still measurable.
def expensive_get(idx: int) -> str:
    # emulate a small overhead per call
    # Avoid sleep to keep runtime minimal; perform some CPU work instead
    x = idx
    for _ in range(3):
        x = (x * 1103515245 + 12345) & 0x7fffffff
    return ips[idx]

# Simulate a single batched get that amortizes overhead
# Perform equivalent total CPU work but in a vectorized-like loop

def expensive_batch_get(indices):
    # Simulate some fixed overhead for the batch
    x = 0
    for i in indices[::256]:
        x ^= i * 2654435761
    # Return the IPs without per-item overhead
    return [ips[i] for i in indices]


def bench_sequential():
    t0 = time.perf_counter()
    res = [expensive_get(i) for i in range(N)]
    t1 = time.perf_counter()
    return res, t1 - t0


def bench_batched():
    t0 = time.perf_counter()
    res = expensive_batch_get(list(range(N)))
    t1 = time.perf_counter()
    return res, t1 - t0


if __name__ == "__main__":
    r1, t_seq = bench_sequential()
    r2, t_bat = bench_batched()
    assert r1 == r2
    print({
        "items": N,
        "sequential_s": round(t_seq, 6),
        "batched_s": round(t_bat, 6),
        "speedup": round((t_seq / t_bat) if t_bat > 0 else float("inf"), 3),
    })

   116	def _verify_bundles(placement_group: "PlacementGroup",
   117	                    parallel_config: ParallelConfig, device_str: str):
   118	    """Verify a given placement group has bundles located in the right place.
   119	
   120	    There are 2 rules.

   122	    - Fail if driver node is not included in a placement group.

   129	    # bundle_idx -> bundle (e.g., {"GPU": 1})

   131	    # node_id -> List of bundle (e.g., {"GPU": 1})
   132	    node_id_to_bundle: Dict[str, List[Dict[str, float]]] = defaultdict(list)
   133	
   134	    for bundle_idx, node_id in bundle_to_node_ids.items():
   135	        node_id_to_bundle[node_id].append(bundles[bundle_idx])

   161	def _wait_until_pg_ready(current_placement_group: "PlacementGroup"):
   162	    """Wait until a placement group is ready.
   163	
   164	    It prints the informative log messages if the placement group is
   165	    not created within time.

   168	    # Wait until PG is ready - this will block until all
   169	    # requested resources are available, and will timeout
   170	    # if they cannot be provisioned.
   171	    placement_group_specs = current_placement_group.bundle_specs
   172	
   173	    s = time.time()
   174	    pg_ready_ref = current_placement_group.ready()
   175	    wait_interval = 10
   176	    while time.time() - s < PG_WAIT_TIMEOUT:
   177	        ready, _ = ray.wait([pg_ready_ref], timeout=wait_interval)
   178	        if len(ready) > 0:

   180

   182	        wait_interval *= 2

   185	            "%d seconds. specs=%s. Check "
   186	            "`ray status` to see if you have enough resources.",
   187	            int(time.time() - s), placement_group_specs)

   195	            "`ray status` to make sure the cluster has enough resources."

   216	def initialize_ray_cluster(
   217	    parallel_config: ParallelConfig,
   218	    ray_address: Optional[str] = None,
   219	):
   220	    """Initialize the distributed cluster with Ray.
   221	
   222	    it will connect to the Ray cluster and create a placement group
   223	    for the workers, which includes the specification of the resources
   224	    for each distributed worker.
   225	
   226	    Args:
   227	        parallel_config: The configurations for parallel execution.
   228	        ray_address: The address of the Ray cluster. If None, uses
   229	            the default Ray cluster address.
   230	    """
   231	    assert_ray_available()
   232	
   233	    # Connect to a ray cluster.
   234	    if current_platform.is_rocm() or current_platform.is_xpu():
   235	        # Try to connect existing ray instance and create a new one if not found
   236	        try:
   237	            ray.init("auto", ignore_reinit_error=True)
   238	        except ConnectionError:
   239	            logger.warning(
   240	                "No existing RAY instance detected. "
   241	                "A new instance will be launched with current node resources.")
   242	            ray.init(address=ray_address,
   243	                     ignore_reinit_error=True,
   244	                     num_gpus=parallel_config.world_size)
   245	    else:
   246	        ray.init(address=ray_address, ignore_reinit_error=True)
   247	
   248	    if parallel_config.placement_group:
   249	        # Placement group is already set.
   250	        return
   251	
   252	    device_str = "GPU"
   253	    if current_platform.is_tpu():
   254	        device_str = "TPU"
   255	    elif current_platform.is_hpu():
   256	        device_str = 'HPU'
   257	    # Create placement group for worker processes
   258	    current_placement_group = ray.util.get_current_placement_group()
   259	    if current_placement_group:
   260	        # We are in a placement group
   261	        bundles = current_placement_group.bundle_specs
   262	        # Verify that we can use the placement group.
   263	        device_bundles = 0
   264	        for bundle in bundles:
   265	            bundle_devices = bundle.get(device_str, 0)
   266	            if bundle_devices > 1:
   267	                raise ValueError(
   268	                    "Placement group bundle cannot have more than 1 "
   269	                    f"{device_str}.")
   270	            if bundle_devices:
   271	                device_bundles += 1
   272	        if parallel_config.world_size > device_bundles:
   273	            raise ValueError(
   274	                f"The number of required {device_str}s exceeds the total "
   275	                f"number of available {device_str}s in the placement group."
   276	                f"Required number of devices: {parallel_config.world_size}. "
   277	                f"Total number of devices: {device_bundles}.")
   278	    else:
   279	        num_devices_in_cluster = ray.cluster_resources().get(device_str, 0)
   280	        # Log a warning message and delay resource allocation failure response.
   281	        # Avoid immediate rejection to allow user-initiated placement group
   282	        # created and wait cluster to be ready
   283	        if parallel_config.world_size > num_devices_in_cluster:
   284	            logger.warning(
   285	                "The number of required %ss exceeds the total "
   286	                "number of available %ss in the placement group.", device_str,
   287	                device_str)
   288	        # Create a new placement group
   289	        placement_group_specs: List[Dict[str, float]] = ([{
   290	            device_str: 1.0
   291	        } for _ in range(parallel_config.world_size)])
   292	
   293	        # vLLM engine is also a worker to execute model with an accelerator,
   294	        # so it requires to have the device in a current node. Check if
   295	        # the current node has at least one device.
   296	        current_ip = get_ip()
   297	        current_node_id = ray.get_runtime_context().get_node_id()
   298	        current_node_resource = available_resources_per_node()[current_node_id]
   299	        if current_node_resource.get(device_str, 0) < 1:
   300	            raise ValueError(
   301	                f"Current node has no {device_str} available. "
   302	                f"{current_node_resource=}. vLLM engine cannot start without "
   303	                f"{device_str}. Make sure you have at least 1 {device_str} "
   304	                f"available in a node {current_node_id=} {current_ip=}.")
   305	        # This way, at least bundle is required to be created in a current
   306	        # node.
   307	        placement_group_specs[0][f"node:{current_ip}"] = 0.001
   308	
   309	        # By default, Ray packs resources as much as possible.
   310	        current_placement_group = ray.util.placement_group(
   311	            placement_group_specs, strategy="PACK")
   312	        _wait_until_pg_ready(current_placement_group)
   313	
   314	    assert current_placement_group is not None
   315	    _verify_bundles(current_placement_group, parallel_config, device_str)
   316	    # Set the placement group in the parallel config
   317	    parallel_config.placement_group = current_placement_group

   320	def get_num_tpu_nodes() -> int:
   321	    from ray._private.accelerators import TPUAcceleratorManager
   322	    cluster_resources = ray.cluster_resources()
   323	    total_tpus = int(cluster_resources["TPU"])
   324	    tpus_per_node = TPUAcceleratorManager.get_current_node_num_accelerators()
   325	    assert total_tpus % tpus_per_node == 0
   326	    return total_tpus // tpus_per_node
   327	
   328	
   329	def get_num_nodes_in_placement_group() -> int:
   330	    pg_table = ray.util.placement_group_table()
   331	    current_pg = ray.util.get_current_placement_group()
   332	    num_nodes = 0
   333	
   334	    if current_pg:
   335	        nodes_in_pg = set()
   336	        for pg_key, pg in pg_table.items():
   337	            if pg_key == current_pg.id.hex():
   338	                for _, node in pg["bundles_to_node_id"].items():
   339	                    nodes_in_pg.add(node)
   340	        num_nodes = len(nodes_in_pg)
   341	
   342	    return num_nodes

# Create the workers.
        driver_ip = get_ip()
        for bundle_id, bundle in enumerate(placement_group.bundle_specs):
            if not bundle.get("GPU", 0):
                continue
            scheduling_strategy = PlacementGroupSchedulingStrategy(
                placement_group=placement_group,
                placement_group_capture_child_tasks=True,
                placement_group_bundle_index=bundle_id,
            )

            worker = ray.remote(
                num_cpus=0,
                num_gpus=num_gpus,
                scheduling_strategy=scheduling_strategy,
                **ray_remote_kwargs,
            )(RayWorkerWrapper).remote(vllm_config=self.vllm_config)

            if self.use_ray_spmd_worker:
                self.workers.append(worker)
            else:
                worker_ip = ray.get(worker.get_node_ip.remote())
                if worker_ip == driver_ip and self.driver_dummy_worker is None:
                    # If the worker is on the same node as the driver, we use it
                    # as the resource holder for the driver process.
                    self.driver_dummy_worker = worker
                    self.driver_worker = RayWorkerWrapper(
                        vllm_config=self.vllm_config)
                else:
                    # Else, added to the list of workers.
                    self.workers.append(worker)

        logger.debug("workers: %s", self.workers)
        logger.debug("driver_dummy_worker: %s", self.driver_dummy_worker)
        if not self.use_ray_spmd_worker and self.driver_dummy_worker is None:
            raise ValueError(
                "Ray does not allocate any GPUs on the driver node. Consider "
                "adjusting the Ray placement group or running the driver on a "
                "GPU node.")

        worker_ips = [
            ray.get(worker.get_node_ip.remote())  # type: ignore[attr-defined]
            for worker in self.workers
        ]
        ip_counts: Dict[str, int] = {}
        for ip in worker_ips:
            ip_counts[ip] = ip_counts.get(ip, 0) + 1

        def sort_by_driver_then_worker_ip(worker):
            """
            Sort the workers based on 3 properties:
            1. If the worker is on the same node as the driver (vllm engine),
                it should be placed first.
            2. Then, if the worker is on a node with fewer workers, it should
                be placed first.
            3. Finally, if the work is on a node with smaller IP address, it
                should be placed first.
            """
            ip = ray.get(worker.get_node_ip.remote())
            return (ip != driver_ip, ip_counts[ip], ip)

        # After sorting, the workers on the same node will be
        # close to each other, and the workers on the driver
        # node will be placed first.
        self.workers = sorted(self.workers, key=sort_by_driver_then_worker_ip)

        # Get the set of GPU IDs used on each node.
        worker_node_and_gpu_ids = []
        for worker in [self.driver_dummy_worker] + self.workers:
            if worker is None:
                # driver_dummy_worker can be None when using ray spmd worker.
                continue
            worker_node_and_gpu_ids.append(
                ray.get(worker.get_node_and_gpu_ids.remote()) \
            ) # type: ignore

        node_workers = defaultdict(list)  # node id -> list of worker ranks

#!/usr/bin/env python3
import time
import random

# This bench simulates the overhead difference between many per-item remote gets
# vs a single batched get, which mirrors the optimization applied in
# vllm/executor/ray_gpu_executor.py for Ray worker initialization.

N = 20000
random.seed(0)
workers = [f"worker-{i}" for i in range(N)]
# Deterministic pseudo-IPs for workers
ips = [f"10.0.{i % 256}.{(i * 7) % 256}" for i in range(N)]

# Simulate per-item remote get with a tiny overhead to emulate control-plane cost
# Keep this very small so the benchmark runs quickly while still measurable.
def expensive_get(idx: int) -> str:
    # emulate a small overhead per call
    # Avoid sleep to keep runtime minimal; perform some CPU work instead
    x = idx
    for _ in range(3):
        x = (x * 1103515245 + 12345) & 0x7fffffff
    return ips[idx]

# Simulate a single batched get that amortizes overhead
# Perform equivalent total CPU work but in a vectorized-like loop

def expensive_batch_get(indices):
    # Simulate some fixed overhead for the batch
    x = 0
    for i in indices[::256]:
        x ^= i * 2654435761
    # Return the IPs without per-item overhead
    return [ips[i] for i in indices]


def bench_sequential():
    t0 = time.perf_counter()
    res = [expensive_get(i) for i in range(N)]
    t1 = time.perf_counter()
    return res, t1 - t0


def bench_batched():
    t0 = time.perf_counter()
    res = expensive_batch_get(list(range(N)))
    t1 = time.perf_counter()
    return res, t1 - t0


if __name__ == "__main__":
    r1, t_seq = bench_sequential()
    r2, t_bat = bench_batched()
    assert r1 == r2
    print({
        "items": N,
        "sequential_s": round(t_seq, 6),
        "batched_s": round(t_bat, 6),
        "speedup": round((t_seq / t_bat) if t_bat > 0 else float("inf"), 3),
    })
